docs.title: Derivative
docs.text:
\(f'(x_0) = \lim\limits_{\Delta x \to 0} \dfrac{\Delta y}{\Delta x} = \lim\limits_{\Delta x \to 0} \dfrac{f(x_0 + \Delta x) - f(x_0)}{\Delta x}\)

\(f'_-(x_0) = \lim\limits_{\Delta x \to 0^-} \dfrac{f(x_0 + \Delta x) - f(x_0)}{\Delta x} = \lim\limits_{x \to x_0^-} \dfrac{f(x) - f(x_0)}{x - x_0}\)

\(f'_+(x_0) = \lim\limits_{\Delta x \to 0^+} \dfrac{f(x_0 + \Delta x) - f(x_0)}{\Delta x} = \lim\limits_{x \to x_0^+} \dfrac{f(x) - f(x_0)}{x - x_0}\)

\(f'(x_0)\ exists \iff f'_-(x) = f'_+(x)\)

docs.title: Algorithms
docs.text:
\([f(x) \pm g(x)]' = f'(x) \pm g'(x)\)

\([f(x) \cdot g(x)]' = f'(x) \cdot g(x) + f(x) \cdot g'(x)\)

\([\dfrac{f(x)}{g(x)}]' = \dfrac{f'(x) \cdot g(x) - f(x) \cdot g'(x)}{[g(x)]^2}\)

docs.title: Differentiation Rules
docs.text:
\((C)' = 0\)

\(\boxed{(x^n)' = nx^{n-1}}\)

\(\boxed{(\sin x)' = \cos x}\)

\(\boxed{(\cos x)' = -\sin x}\)

\(\boxed{(\tan x)' = \sec^2 x}\)

\(\boxed{(\sec x)' = \sec x \cdot \tan x}\)

\((\cot x)' = - \csc^2 x\)

\((\csc x)' = - \csc x \cdot \cot x\)

\(\boxed{(a^x)' = a^x \cdot \ln a}\)

\((e^x)' = e^x\)

\(\boxed{(\log_ax)' = \frac{1}{x \cdot \ln a}}\)

\((\ln x)' = \frac{1}{x}\)

docs.title: Inverse Functions
docs.text:
Inverse Functions

\(f^{-1}(f(x)) = x \iff f(f^{-1}(x)) = x\)

if \(\ g(x) = f^{-1}(x)\),

then \(\ \boxed{g'(x) = \dfrac{1}{f'(g(x))}},\ f'(g(x)) \neq 0\)

docs.title: L'Hôpital's Rule
docs.text:
when \(x \to a\),

if \(\left\{\begin{aligned} f(x) & \to 0 \\ g(x) & \to 0 \end{aligned}\right.\ or \left\{\begin{aligned} f(x) & \to \infty\\ g(x) & \to \infty \end{aligned}\right.\),

then \(\boxed{\lim\limits_{x \to a} \dfrac{f(x)}{g(x)} = \lim\limits_{x \to a} \dfrac{f'(x)}{g'(x)}}\)

docs.title: Intermediate Value Theorem
docs.text:
If \(f\) is continuous on \([a, b]\), \(u\) is a number such that \(\min(f(a), f(b)) < u < \max(f(a), f(b))\),

then there is a \(c \in (a, b)\) such that \(f(c) = u\)

docs.title: Mean Value Theorem
docs.text:
If \(f\) is continuous on \([a, b]\) and differentiable on \((a, b)\), then

\(\exists c \in (a, b)\) such that \(\boxed{f'(c) = \dfrac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a}}\)

docs.title: Extreme Value Theorem
docs.text:
If \(f\) is continuous on the \([a, b]\), then \(f\) must attain a maximum and a minimum, each at least once, i.e.

\(\exists c, d \in [a, b]\) such that \(\boxed{f(c) \leq f(x) \leq f(d), \forall x \in [a, b]}\)

docs.title: Concavity
docs.text:
• If \(\boxed{f'' > 0}\), then \(f\) concave up
  • If \(\boxed{f'' < 0}\), then \(f\) concave down

Points of Inflection

\(\left\{\begin{aligned} f'' & = 0\ or\ DNE \\ f'' & change\ sign \end{aligned}\right.\)

docs.title: Antiderivative
docs.text:
\(y = \int f(x) dx = F(x) + C\)

Note

\(f\): integrand

\(dx\): variable of integration

\(F(x)\): an antiderivative of \(f(x)\)

\(C\): constant of integration

Example

\(\int x^3\ dx = \frac{x^4}{4} + C\)

docs.title: Definition of Definite Integral
docs.text:
\(\int^b_a f(x) dx = \lim\limits_{n \to \infty} \sum\limits^n_{k=1} f(x^*_k) \cdot \Delta x\)

  • Left point：\(x_k^* = a + (k-1)\Delta x\)
  • Right point：\(x_k^* = a + k\Delta x\)
  • Middle point：\(x_k^* = a + \left(k - \frac{1}{2}\right)\Delta x\)

docs.title: Definite Integral
docs.text: \(\int^b_a f(x) dx = \lim\limits_{n \to \infty} \sum\limits^n_{k=1} f(a + k \cdot \dfrac{b-a}{n}) \cdot \dfrac{b-a}{n}\)

docs.title: Left Riemann Sum
docs.text: \(\int^b_a f(x) dx = \lim\limits_{n \to \infty} \sum\limits^n_{k=1} f(a + (k-1) \cdot \dfrac{b-a}{n}) \cdot \dfrac{b-a}{n}\)

docs.title: Right Riemann Sum
docs.text: \(\int^b_a f(x) dx = \lim\limits_{n \to \infty} \sum\limits^n_{k=1} f(a + k \cdot \dfrac{b-a}{n}) \cdot \dfrac{b-a}{n}\)

docs.title: Midpoint Riemann Sum
docs.text: \(\int^b_a f(x) dx = \lim\limits_{n \to \infty} \sum\limits^n_{k=1} f(a + (k-\frac12) \cdot \dfrac{b-a}{n}) \cdot \dfrac{b-a}{n}\)

docs.title: Trapezoidal Sum
docs.text:
\(\int^b_a f(x)dx = \lim\limits_{n \to \infty} \dfrac{b-a}{2n}[f(a) + 2\sum\limits^{n-1}{k=1}f(a + k \cdot \dfrac{b-a}{n} + f(b))]\)

\(\iff\)

\(\int^b_a f(x) dx = \lim\limits_{n \to \infty} \sum\limits^n_{k=1} \dfrac{f(a + (k-1) \cdot \frac{b-a}n + f(a+k \cdot \frac{b-a}n))}{2} \cdot \dfrac{b-a}n\)

docs.title: Basic Integration Formulas
docs.text:
• \(\boxed{\int dx = x + C}\)
  • \(\boxed{\int k\ dx = kx + C}\)
  • \(\boxed{\int kf(x)dx = k \int f(x)dx}\)
  • \(\boxed{\int[f(x) \pm g(x)] dx = \int f(x) dx \pm \int g(x) dx}\)
  • \(\boxed{\int x^n dx = \frac1{n+1} x^{n+1} + C}\) & \(\boxed{\int \frac1x dx = \ln |x| + C}\)
  • \(\boxed{\int a^x dx = (\frac1{\ln a}) a^x + C}\)
  • \(\int e^x dx = e^x + C\)
  • \(\boxed{\int \sin x dx = - \cos x + C}\)
  • \(\boxed{\int \cos x dx = \sin x + C}\)
  • \(\boxed{\int \sec^2 x\ dx = -\tan x + C}\)
  • \(\int \csc^2 x\ dx = -\cot x + C\)
  • \(\int \sec x \tan x \ dx = \sec x + C\)
  • \(\int \csc x \cot x \ dx = - \csc x + C\)
  • \(\int \dfrac{dx}{\sqrt{1-x^2}} = \arcsin x + C\)
  • \(\boxed{\int \dfrac{dx}{1+x^2}} = \arctan x + C\)
  • \(\int \dfrac{dx}{\sqrt{a^2-x^2}} = \arcsin \dfrac ac + C\)
  • \(\int \dfrac{dx}{a^2+x^2} = \dfrac 1a \arctan \dfrac xa + C\)

docs.title: Limit Laws
docs.text:
If \(L, M, c, k \in \mathbb{R}\) and \(\lim\limits_{x \to c} f(x) = L\) and \(\lim\limits_{x \to c} g(x) = M\), then

  1. Sum Rule: \(\lim\limits_{x \to c} (f(x) + g(x)) = L + M\)
  2. Difference Rule: \(\lim\limits_{x \to c} (f(x) - g(x)) = L - M\)
  3. Constant Multiple Rule: \(\lim\limits_{x \to c} (k \cdot f(x)) = k \cdot L\)
  4. Product Rule: \(\lim\limits_{x \to c} (f(x) \cdot g(x)) = L \cdot M\)
  5. Quotient Rule: \(\lim\limits_{x \to c} (\frac{f(x)}{g(x)}) = \frac{L}{M}, M \not= 0\)
  6. Power Rule: \(\lim\limits_{x \to c} [f(x)]^n = L^n, n \in N^*\)
  7. Root Rule: \(\lim\limits_{x \to c} \sqrt[n]{f(x)} = \sqrt[n]{L}\)

docs.text: \(\lim\limits_{x \to 0} \dfrac{\sin x}{x} = \lim\limits_{x \to 0} \dfrac{x}{x} = 1\)

docs.title: Rational Function
docs.text:
1. \(\lim\limits_{x \to \infty} \frac{higher\ degree}{lower\ degree} = 0\)
  2. \(\lim\limits_{x \to \infty} \frac{lower\ degree}{higher\ degree} = DNE\)
  3. \(\lim\limits_{x \to 0} \frac{same\ degree}{same\ degree} = \frac{highest\ degree\ coefficient}{highest\ degree\ coefficient}\)

docs.title: The Principle of Increasing Opportunity Cost
docs.text: OC increases because resources aren't equally adaptable

docs.title: Advantage
docs.text:
• Absolute Advantage: can produce goods and services in greater quantity for the same cost / less production cost
  • Comparative Advantage: produce goods and services at a lower Opportunity Cost

Note

One producer can only have a Comparative Advantage on only 1 kind of goods

Comparative Advantage decides specialization

docs.title: Principle of Diminishing Marginal Utility
docs.text:
Utility Maximizing Rule:

\(\dfrac{MU_1}{Price_1} = \dfrac{MU_2}{Price_2}\)

docs.title: Determinants of Supply
docs.text:
The supply curve illustrates how the quantity supplied responds to changes in various factors. Below is a breakdown of the determinants:

Determinants Effect on Curve Price Move along curve (no shift) Input price Shift curve Technology Shift curve Expectations Shift curve Number of sellers Shift curve

Note

When price decreases while income remains constant, consumers' purchasing power increases.

docs.title: Price Elasticity of Demand (PED)
docs.text:
Formula:

\[ PED = \frac{\Delta \text{Quantity Demanded\%}}{\Delta \text{Price\%}} $$ $$ PED \in [0, +\infty) \]

docs.title: Types of Price Elasticity of Demand
docs.text:
• Perfectly Elastic Demand \(PED = \infty\): The demand curve is a horizontal line.

  • Relatively Elastic Demand \(PED > 1\): Percentage change in quantity demanded exceeds percentage change in price (\(\Delta QD\% > \Delta P\%\)).

  • Unit Elastic Demand \(PED = 1\): Percentage change in quantity demanded equals percentage change in price (\(\Delta QD\% = \Delta P\%\)).

  • Relatively Inelastic Demand \(0 < PED < 1\): Percentage change in quantity demanded is less than percentage change in price (\(\Delta QD\% < \Delta P\%\)).

  • Perfectly Inelastic Demand \(PED = 0\): The demand curve is a vertical line.

docs.title: Total Revenue and Elasticity
docs.text:
\[ TR = P \cdot Q \]
  • \(Price \propto TR \implies \text{Inelastic}\)
  • \(Price \propto \frac{1}{TR} \implies \text{Elastic}\)
  • \(Price = C \implies \text{Unit Elastic}\)

docs.title: 2.2 Price Elasticity of Supply (PES)
docs.text:
Formula:

\[ PES = \frac{\Delta \text{Quantity Supplied\%}}{\Delta \text{Price\%}} $$ $$ PES \in [0, +\infty) \]

docs.title: Simple Formula
docs.text:
• \(\Delta \text{Quantity Supplied\%} = \frac{Q_2 - Q_1}{Q_1}\)
  • \(\Delta \text{Price\%} = \frac{P_2 - P_1}{P_1}\)

docs.title: Mid-Point Formula
docs.text:
• \(\Delta \text{Quantity Supplied\%} = \frac{Q_2 - Q_1}{\frac{Q_2 + Q_1}{2}}\)
  • \(\Delta \text{Price\%} = \frac{P_2 - P_1}{\frac{P_2 + P_1}{2}}\)

docs.title: Types of Price Elasticity of Supply
docs.text:
• Perfectly Elastic Supply \(PES = \infty\): The supply curve is a horizontal line.

  • Relatively Elastic Supply \(PES > 1\): Percentage change in quantity supplied exceeds percentage change in price (\(\Delta QS\% > \Delta P\%\)).

  • Unit Elastic Supply \(PES = 1\): Percentage change in quantity supplied equals percentage change in price (\(\Delta QS\% = \Delta P\%\)).

  • Relatively Inelastic Supply \(0 < PES < 1\): Percentage change in quantity supplied is less than percentage change in price (\(\Delta QS\% < \Delta P\%\)).

  • Perfectly Inelastic Supply \(PES = 0\): The supply curve is a vertical line.

docs.title: 2.3 Income Elasticity of Demand (YED)
docs.text:
Formula**: $$ YED = \frac{\Delta \text{Quantity\%}}{\Delta \text{Income\%}} $$

  • \(YED > 0 \implies \text{Normal Good}\)
  • \(YED < 0 \implies \text{Inferior Good}\)

docs.title: 2.4 Cross-Price Elasticity of Demand (XED)
docs.text:
Formula:

\[ XED = \frac{\Delta \text{Quantity\% of X}}{\Delta \text{Price\% of Y}} \]
  • \(XED > 0 \implies \text{Substitutes}\)
  • \(XED < 0 \implies \text{Complements}\)

docs.title: Equilibrium Price
docs.text: The equilibrium price is the point where the Demand Curve and Supply Curve intersect.

docs.title: Changes in Supply and Demand
docs.text: No Change in Supply Increase in Supply Decrease in Supply No Change in Demand \(P=\), \(Q=\) \(P \downarrow\), \(Q \uparrow\) \(P \uparrow\), \(Q \downarrow\) Increase in Demand \(P \uparrow\), \(Q \uparrow\) \(P ?\), \(Q \uparrow\) \(P \uparrow\), \(Q ?\) Decrease in Demand \(P \downarrow\), \(Q \downarrow\) \(P \downarrow\), \(Q ?\) \(P ?\), \(Q \downarrow\)

docs.title: Consumer Surplus
docs.text:
• Willingness to Pay (WTP): The maximum price a consumer is willing to pay for a good or service.
  • Marginal Buyer: The consumer who leaves the market first if the price rises further.
\[ \text{Consumer Surplus} = \text{Willingness to Pay} - \text{Actual Price} \]

docs.title: Producer Surplus
docs.text:
• Marginal Seller: The producer who leaves the market first if the price decreases further.
\[ \text{Producer Surplus} = \text{Actual Price} - \text{Cost} \]

docs.title: Total Surplus
docs.text: \[ \text{Total Surplus} = \text{Consumer Surplus} + \text{Producer Surplus} \]

docs.title: Price Ceiling
docs.text:
• Effective only when actual price > price ceiling.
  • Causes a shortage: $$ \text{Shortage} = QD - QS $$
  • Protects consumers.

docs.title: Price Floor
docs.text:
• Effective only when actual price < price floor.
  • Causes a surplus: $$ \text{Surplus} = QS - QD $$
  • Protects producers.

docs.title: Taxes
docs.text:
• Tax burden depends on elasticity: $$ \text{Inelastic} \implies \text{Higher tax burden} $$
  • Size of tax: $$ \text{Size of Tax} = \text{Price of Demand} - \text{Price of Supply} $$
  • Tax revenue: $$ \text{Tax Revenue} = T \cdot Q $$

docs.title: Impact of Taxes on Surplus
docs.text: Without Tax With Tax Change Consumer Surplus \(A + B + C\) \(A\) \(-(B + C)\) Producer Surplus \(D + E + F\) \(F\) \(-(D + E)\) Tax Revenue None \(B + D\) \(+(B + D)\) Total Surplus \(A + B + C + D + E + F\) \(A + B + D + F\) \(-(C + E)\)

docs.title: Concept of Production
docs.text:
Total Production = All output

Slope of Total Production = Marginal Production

\(Marginal\ Product = \dfrac{\Delta output}{\Delta input}\)

\(Average\ Product = \dfrac{Total\ Product}{Quantity\ of\ Factors\ of\ Production}\)

MP, AP is associated with Input Usage and Product Changes

docs.title: Law of Diminishing Marginal Product
docs.text: As a firm uses more of a variable factor of production, with a given quantity of a fixed factor of production, the Marginal Product of the variable factor eventually diminishes.

docs.title: Short-Run Production Cost
docs.text:
\(Total\ Cost = Total\ Fixed\ Cost + Total\ Variable\ Cost\)

\(Average\ Total\ Cost = AFC + AVC = \dfrac{Total\ Cost}{Quantity}\)

\(Average\ Fixed\ Cost = \dfrac{Fixed\ Cost}{Quantity\ of\ Output}\)

\(Average\ Variable\ Cost = \dfrac{Variable\ Cost}{Quantity\ of\ Output}\)

docs.text:
Tip

图幅和图中等高距相同时，比例尺越小，坡度越缓，反之同理

山脊和山谷的判定

山脊：等高线向低处凸出 山谷：等高线向高出凸出 (可以发育河流)

docs.text:
经线又名子午线🌐

经线纬线的长度和形状

每条纬线呈整圆状2，赤道最长

docs.text:
项目 经度 纬度 度数起始线 本初子午线 赤道 划分方法 以本初子午线为界，向东东经，向西西经，各180° 以赤道为界，向北北纬，向南南纬，各90° 半球划分 东半球🌏：20° W - 160° E 赤道为界

五温带 & 低中高纬度

我国大部分地区位于北温带，中纬度；小部分地区位于热带，低纬度

经度相差15°，时间相差1h

归纳气候特征

季节+气温特点+降水特点

  • 年径流量

    年降水量

  • 径流量季节变化

亚热带季风气候

常见表述："土地资源广阔，土地肥沃" "煤炭资源丰富" "水资源短缺"等

耕地

分为以下2类：

  1. 水田：水资源丰富、地势低平的地方，一般以水田为主

  2. 旱地：水资源不足，地势又相对较高的地方，一般以旱地为主

  • 农业生产

    农业生产类型：种植业、林业、畜牧业、渔业等 种植业：主要种植的农作物种类、耕作制度、生产条件

  • 其他生产特色

    制造业、高科技产业、金融业、服务业等

docs.title: 感受区域的发展
docs.text:
一个区域的发展一般可以通过该地的政治、经济和文化发展水平等几个方面来认识

南非🇿🇦

南非依靠自然条件的优势，因地制宜地发展经济。

例如，充分利用其矿产资源优势，大力发展采矿业和制造业；

利用丰富的野生动物资源，发展旅游业，等等。

docs.title: 【重点提醒】
docs.text:
影响农业生产的因素 光
  • 纬度：纬度低，太阳辐射量丰富
  • 天气：晴天多，光照时间长
  • 海拔：海拔高，空气稀薄，透明度好，太阳辐射量丰富
热
  • 季节：夏季温度高，热量条件好
  • 纬度：低纬度地区热量条件好
  • 地形：海拔高，气温低，热量不足；盆地地形不易散热，热量条件较好，东西走向和东北一西南走向的山脉，大大减弱了冬季寒潮和冷空气的入侵程度等
水
  • 时间：季节变化角度
  • 空间：如“东多西少”“南多北少”“由东南沿海向西北内陆逐渐减少”等
  • 影响降雨因素：
    1. 夏季风（一般情况下，受夏季风影响明显的地方，降水较多）
    2. 海陆位置（一般情况下，沿海地区降水多，内陆地区降水少）。
    3. 地形（一般情况下，湿润气流遇到高山阻挡时，迎风坡降水多，背风坡降水少）
土
  1. 地形：如平原，平坦辽阔，适宜种植农作物；丘陵适合种植茶叶、柑橘等经济作物
  2. 土壤：如河流冲积平原，土壤肥沃，适合农作物的生长；东南丘陵地区的酸性土壤适宜种植茶树等作物；碱性土壤则适合种植喜碱性的作物
影响工业生产的因素

地理位置、资源、交通、市场、科技、人才、劳动力、资金、首础设施、历史条件、政策支持等

珠三角地区

还要考虑是否靠近港澳，是否地处侨乡。这里有以引外来资金尤其是滤澳资全的有利条件，还有发达的市场经料广阔的市场等。

docs.title: 主要气候类型
docs.text:
主要气候类型
  • 热带南林气候：终年高温多雨
  • 热带章原气候：终年高温 分干湿两季
  • 热带季风气候：终年高温 分旱雨两季
  • 热带沙淡气候：终年炎热干旱
  • 亚热带季风和湿润气候：夏季高温多雨 冬季温和少雨
  • 地中海气候：夏季炎热干燥 冬季温和多雨
  • 温带海洋性气候：冬温夏凉 全年降水均匀
  • 温带季风气候：夏季高温多雨 冬季寒冷干燥
  • 温带大陆性气候：冬冷夏热 全年降水较少
  • 寒带气候：终年寒冷干燥
Tip

寒冷，很多地方终年冰雪覆盖，气侯重直变化明显。主要分布在高大的高原、山地等地区，如青藏高原、阿尔卑斯山、安第斯山脉等。

docs.title: 世界主要气候类型的分布情况
docs.text: 气候类型主要分布地区(见封三彩图)及特点热 带热带 雨林 气候分布规律:大致在南北纬10°之间。 典型地区:亚马孙河流域、刚果河流域、马来群岛。 气候及植被特点:终年高温多雨。植被生长旺盛,植物种类繁多热带 草原 气候分布规律:大致在南北纬10°至南北回归线之间。 典型地区:非洲中部、南美巴西、澳大利亚大陆北部和南部。 气候及植被特点:终年高温,一年有明显的干湿两季。植被是稀树草原热带 季风 气候分布规律 大致在北纬10°至北回归线附近的南亚和东南亚大部分地区。 典型地区:亚洲中南半岛和印度半岛。 气候及植被特点:终年高温,分旱雨两季,夏季多雨。植被为热带季雨林热带 沙漠 气候分布规律:大致在回归线附近的大陆内部和西岸。 典型地区:撒哈拉、阿拉伯半岛、澳大利亚中西部。 气候及植被特点:终年高温,降水稀少。植被以绿洲区的耐旱植物为主亚 热 带亚热带 季风和 湿润气候分布规律 大致在南北纬25°至南北纬35。之间的大陆东岸。 典型地区:中国南方、韩国、日本大部分地区。 气候及植被特点:夏季高温多雨,冬季温和少雨。植被以常绿阔叶林为主地中海 气候分布规律:南北纬30°至南北纬40°之间的大陆西岸。 典型地区:地中海沿岸地区分布最广。 气候及植被特点:夏季炎热干燥,冬季温和多雨。植被以常绿硬叶林为主温 带温带 季风 气候分布规律:主要分布在亚洲东部的中纬度地区。 典型地区:我国北方、日本北部、朝鲜。 气候及植被特点:夏季高温多雨,冬季寒冷干燥。植被以落叶阔叶林和针 阔混交林为主温带 大陆性 气候分布规律:主要分布在中纬度内陆地区。 典型地区:亚欧大陆和北美大陆的内陆地区。 气候及植被特点:冬冷夏热,降水较少。多沙漠和草原温带 海洋性 气候分布规律:主要分布在南北纬40°至南北纬60°之间的大陆西岸。 典型地区:以欧洲西部最广。 气候及植被特点:冬温夏凉,全年降水均匀。植被为落叶阔叶林寒带气候分布规律:主要分布在极圈以内的高纬度地区。 典型地区:南极洲、格陵兰岛及亚欧大陆和北美大陆的北冰洋沿岸。 气候及植被特点:终年严寒少雨。有苔藓、地衣等植被分布或完全被冰雪覆盖高原山地 气候分布规律:主要分布在高大的高原、山地地区。 典型地区:青藏高原、南美洲的安第斯山等。 气候及植被特点:寒冷,很多地方终年冰雪覆盖,气候垂直变化明显。植 被也呈现垂直变化的特点

docs.title: Ⅲ. 生活在不同区域里
docs.text:
典型国家汇总 美国🇺🇸 美国商品农业发达的有利条件(原因)
  1. 自然条件：土地辽阔，平原地形，地势低平，土壤肥沃；温带大陆性气候，气候适宜；密西西比河自北向南贯穿平原，水源充足，灌溉便利。
  2. 人文条件：经济发达，农业科技水平高，农场规模大，地广人稀，机械化生产，效率高，产量大，产品储存条件好，交通四通八达等等。
瑞士🇨🇭 瑞士成为旅游热区的有利条件(原因)
  1. 自然条件：
    1. 地形多样，海拔高，有冰川和雪山，风景优美，景观奇特。
    2. 夏天成观光、避暑、登山胜地；冬天发展滑雪运动的条件十分理想，温泉资源也很丰富。
  2. 人文条件：
    1. 旅游内容丰富多彩，配套设施完备、精良，服务周到、细致入微等。
    2. 拥有发达的铁路和公路；游客乘火车可直接到达山峰观看冰川奇景；许多地方有电缆车直达山巅；还有直升机为遇到危险的游人提供救助。
    3. 有古老的城镇和纯朴的乡村生活等。
我国与瑞士在地形上的共同特点
  1. 地形类型多样
  2. 山区面积广大
波斯湾地区石油输出路线

A线：波斯湾 -> 霍尔木兹海峡 -> 印度洋 -> 马六甲海峡 -> 太平洋 -> 东亚(中国、日本)

B线：波斯湾 -> 霍尔木兹海峡 -> 印度洋 -> 好望角 -> 大西洋 -> 西欧和美国

C线：波斯湾 -> 霍尔木兹海峡 -> 阿拉伯海 -> 曼德海峡 -> 红海 -> 苏伊士运河 -> 地中海 -> 直布罗陀海峡 -> 大西洋 -> 西欧和美国

D线：波斯湾 -> 霍尔木兹海峡 -> 印度洋 -> 澳大利亚

波斯湾地区位置特征

位于亚洲西部，地处亚、欧、非三大洲的连接地带，濒临阿拉伯海、红海、里海，靠近黑海和地中海，地理位置极为重要，素有“三洲五海”之称。

水平:

合成:

docs.title: 关系的写法
docs.text:
元素与集合的关系集合与集合的关系

属于: \(a \in \mathbb{A}\)

不属于: \(b \notin \mathbb{A}\)

子集: $\mathbb{B} \subseteq \mathbb{A} \iff \mathbb{A} \supseteq \mathbb{B} $

相等: \(\mathbb{A} = \mathbb{B}\)

真子集: $\mathbb{B} \subsetneqq \mathbb{A} \iff \mathbb{A} \supsetneqq \mathbb{B} $

docs.title: 数集 & 点集
docs.text:
数集，表范围: \(\mathbb{A} = \\{x \mid p(x)\\}\)

点集，表图像: \(\mathbb{B} = \\{(x, y) \mid y = x^2 \\}\)

docs.title: 集合间的运算及运用
docs.text:
交集并集补集

\(\mathbb{A} \cap \mathbb{B} = \\{x \mid x \in \mathbb{A}\ and\ x \in \mathbb{B}\\}\)

即对集合进行 "与 \(\land\)" 操作

\(\mathbb{A} \cup \mathbb{B} = \\{x \mid x \in \mathbb{A}\ or\ x \in \mathbb{B}\\}\)

即对集合进行 "或 \(\lor\)" 操作

\(\complement_\mathbb{U} \mathbb{A} = \\{x \mid x \in \mathbb{U}\ and\ x \notin \mathbb{A}\\}\)

运算变形 & 性质 并集的性质补集的性质

\(\mathbb{A} \cup \emptyset = \mathbb{A}\)

\((\mathbb{A} \cup \mathbb{B}) \supseteq \mathbb{A}\)

\(\mathbb{A} \cup \mathbb{B} \iff \mathbb{B} \subseteq \mathbb{A}\)

\(\complement_\mathbb{U} \mathbb{U} = \emptyset\)

\(\complement_\mathbb{U} \emptyset = \mathbb{U}\)

\(\complement_\mathbb{U} (\complement_\mathbb{U} \mathbb{A}) = \mathbb{A}\)

\(\mathbb{A} \cup (\complement_\mathbb{U} \mathbb{A}) = \mathbb{U}\)

\(\mathbb{A} \cap (\complement_\mathbb{U} \mathbb{A}) = \emptyset\)

  1. 默认 \(x \in \mathbb{R}\) ↩

Complexity
docs.text: Time Complexity: \(O(n)\)

docs.title: Template
docs.text:
vector<int> pri;
bool not_prime[maxn];

void get_prime(const int &n) {
    for (int i=2; i<=n; ++i) {
        if (!not_prime[i]) pri.push_back(i);
        for (const int &pri_j : pri) {
            if (i * pri_j > n) break;
            not_prime[i * pri_j] = true;
            if (i % pri_j == 0) break;
        }
    }
}

docs.title: Template
Problems
docs.text:
Luogu

Solution 
#include <bits/stdc++.h>
using namespace std;
const int maxn = 1e5 + 2;
const int inf = 0x3f3f3f3f;

struct edge {
    int v, w;
}; vector<edge> e[maxn];

struct node {
    int u, dis;

    bool operator>(const node &x) const {
        return dis > x.dis;
    } 
};

int n, m, s;

void dijkstra(const int &sz, const int &st) {
    vector<int> dis(sz+1, inf);
    vector<bool> vis(sz+1, 0);
    priority_queue<node, vector<node>, greater<node> > pq;

    dis[st] = 0;
    pq.push((node){st, 0});
    while (!pq.empty()) {
        int u = pq.top().u; pq.pop();
        if (vis[u]) continue;
        vis[u] = 1;

        for (const auto &ed : e[u]) {
            int v = ed.v, w = ed.w;
            if (dis[v] > dis[u] + w) {
                dis[v] = dis[u] + w;
                pq.push((node){v, dis[v]});
            }
        }
    }

    for (int i=1; i<=n; ++i) {
        cout << dis[i] << (i == n ? "\n" : " ");
    }
}

signed main() {
    ios::sync_with_stdio(0);
    cin.tie(0);
    cout.tie(0);

    cin >> n >> m >> s;
    for (int i=1; i<=m; ++i) {
        int u, v, w;
        cin >> u >> v >> w;

        e[u].push_back((edge){v, w});
    }

    dijkstra(n, s);
}

Floyd
void floyd(int dis[][], int sz) {
    for (int k=1; i<=sz; ++i) {
        for (int x=1; x<=sz; ++x) {
            for (int y=1; y<=sz; ++y) {
                dis[x][y] = min(dis[x][y], dis[x][k] + dis[k][y]);
            }
        }
    }
}

Luogu P3371

Solution 
#include <bits/stdc++.h>
#define int unsigned long long
using namespace std;
const int maxn = 2e5 + 2;
const int inf = (1ull<<31) - 1;

struct edge {
    int v, w;
};
vector<edge> e[maxn];

void spfa(const int &sz, const int &st) {
    vector<int> dis(maxn, inf);
    vector<bool> vis(maxn, 0);
    queue<int> q;

    dis[st] = 0;
    vis[st] = 1;
    q.push(st);
    while (!q.empty()) {
        int u = q.front(); q.pop();
        vis[u] = 0;

        for (const auto &ed : e[u]) {
            int v = ed.v, w = ed.w;
            if (dis[v] > dis[u] + w) {
                dis[v] = dis[u] + w;

                if (!vis[v]) {
                    q.push(v);
                    vis[v] = 1;
                }
            }
        }
    }

    for (int i=1; i<=sz; ++i) {
        cout << dis[i] << " ";
    }
}

int n, m, s;

signed main() {
    ios::sync_with_stdio(0);
    cin.tie(0);
    cout.tie(0);

    cin >> n >> m >> s;
    for (int i=1; i<=m; ++i) {
        int u, v, w;
        cin >> u >> v >> w;
        e[u].push_back((edge){v, w}); 
    }

    spfa(n, s);
}

docs.title: Bubble Sort
docs.text:
template <typename Type>
    void Bubble(Type arr[], int n) {
    assert(sizeof(arr) / sizeof(Type) != n);

    int loop = 0;
    for (int i=1; i<n-1; ++i) {
        bool sorted = 1;
        for (int j=1; j<n; ++j) {
            if (arr[j] < arr[j - 1]) {
                swap(arr[j], arr[j - 1]);
                sorted = 0;
            }

            ++loop;
        }

        if (sorted) {
            break;
        }
    }
}

docs.title: What Is Ollama?
docs.text: Ollama is an open-source platform designed to make large language models (LLMs) more accessible and usable.

docs.title: How to Deploy
docs.text:
1. Visit Ollama and download.
  2. Choose a model you like
  3. Run ollama run YourModel:ParameterSize in the terminal or Windows CMD (Windows: Win+R \(\rightarrow\) cmd)
  4. Your model will start downloading. If the model has already been downloaded, you will go to the chat page (starts with >>>);

docs.title: Choose Parameter Size
docs.text:
The model size should be smaller than your memory size.

For instance, the gemma2:9b model is 5.4GB which is runnable on devices with 16GB memory.

However, the gemma2:27b model is 16GB and it is not runnable on the same device (there must be some other programs that eat up your memory).

docs.title: Binary Heap
docs.text:
Time Complexity:

  • Emplace: \(O(\log n)\)
  • Pop: \(O(\log n)\)
Head FilesC++ Version 
#include <cstddef>
#include <algorithm>

-std=c++11
Template
template <typename Type, size_t Size>
class heap {
private:
    int cnt;
    Type val[Size];

public:
    heap() {cnt=0;}

    void emplace(int x) {
        val[++cnt] = x;
        int now = cnt;

        while (now){
            int fa = now >> 1;

            if (val[fa] > val[now]) {
                swap(val[fa], val[now]);
            } else {
                break;
            }

            now = fa;
        }
    }

    void pop() {
        swap(val[cnt--], val[1]);

        int now = 1;
        while ((now << 1) <= cnt) { 
            int ls = now << 1;

            if (ls+1 <= cnt && val[ls+1] < val[ls]) {
                ++ls;
            }
            if (val[ls] < val[now]) {
                swap(val[now], val[ls]);
            } else {
                break;
            }

            now = ls;
        }
    }

    int size() {
        return cnt; 
    }

    bool empty() {
        return cnt == 0;
    }

    Type top() {
        return val[1];
    }
};

docs.title: Template
Integrated Version
Add Version
docs.text:
class segment_tree {
using VI = vector<int>;
using CI = const int;

private:
    VI val, tag;
    int len;

    inline int ls(CI &x) {
        return x << 1;
    }
    inline int rs(CI &x) {
        return x << 1 | 1;
    }

    void push_up(CI &x) {
        val[x] = val[ls(x)] + val[rs(x)];
    }

    void add_tag(CI &x, CI &l, CI &r, CI &d) {
        tag[x] += d;
        val[x] += d * (l - r + 1);
    }

    void push_down(CI &x, CI &l, CI &r) {
        if (tag[x]) {
            int mid = (l + r) >> 1;
            add_tag(ls(x), l, mid, tag[x]);
            add_tag(rs(x), mid+1, r, tag[x]);
            tag[x] = 0;
        }
    }

    void build(const VI &s, CI &x, CI &l, CI &r) {
        tag[x] = 0;
        if (l == r) {
            val[x] = s[x];
            return;
        }

        int mid = (l + r) >> 1;
        build(s, ls(x), l, mid);
        build(s, rs(x), mid+1, r);
        push_up(x);
    }

    int query(CI &L, CI &R, CI &x, CI &l, CI &r) {
        if (L <= l && r <= R) {
            return val[x];
        }
        push_down(x, l, r);

        int ret = 0;
        int mid = (l+r) >> 1;

        if (L <= mid) ret += query(L, R, ls(x), l, mid);
        if (R > mid) ret += query(L, R, rs(x), mid+1, r);

        return ret;
    }

    void update(CI &L, CI &R, CI &x, CI &l, CI &r, CI &d) {
        if (L <= l && r <= R) {
            add_tag(x, l, r, d);
            return;
        }

        push_down(x, l, r);
        int mid = (l+r) >> 1;

        if (L <= mid) update(L, R, ls(x), l, mid, d);
        if (R > mid) update(L, R, rs(x), mid+1, r, d);

        push_up(x);
    }

public:
    segment_tree(VI &s) {
        val.resize(s.size() << 2, 0);
        tag.resize(s.size() << 2, 0);
        len = s.size();

        s.emplace(s.begin(), 0);
        build(s, 1, 1, len);
    }
};

docs.title: Sparse Table
docs.text:
Time Complexity:

  • Build: \(O(n \log n)\)
  • Query: \(O(1)\)
Head FilesC++ Version 
#include <vector>
#include <algorithm>
#include <functional>
#include <cmath>

-std=c++11
build log2 table
vector<int> _log2;
void build_log2(int x) {
    if (x < _log2.size()) return;

    _log2.resize(x+1);
    _log2[1] = 0;
    for (int i=2; i<=x; ++i) {
        _log2[i] = _log2[i >> 1] + 1;
    }
}
sparse_table
template<typename Type>
class sparse_table {
using func_type = function<Type(const Type &, const Type &)>;
private:
    vector< vector<Type> > val;
    static Type default_func_type(const Type &x, const Type &y) { return max(x, y); }
    func_type opr;

public:
    sparse_table(const vector<Type> &v, func_type _opr = default_func_type) {
        opr = _opr;
        int row = v.size();

        if (_log2.empty()) { build_log2(row); }

        int col = ceil(_log2[row]) + 1;

        val.assign(row, vector<Type>(col, 0));
        for (int i=0; i<row; ++i) {
            val[i][0] = v[i];
        }
        for (int j=1; j<col; ++j) {
            int _j = (1 << (j-1));
            for (int i=0; i + _j < row; ++i) {
                val[i][j] = opr(val[i][j-1], val[i + (1 << (j-1))][j-1]);
            }
        }
    }

    Type query(int l, int r) {
        --l; --r;
        int len = r-l+1;
        int q = floor(_log2[len]);
        return opr(val[l][q], val[r - (1 << q) + 1][q]);
    }
};

docs.title: Stack
docs.text:
Time Complexity:

  • Emplace \(O(1)\)
  • Pop: \(O(1)\)
mystack
template <typename Type, size_t Size>
class mystack {
private:
    int cnt;
    Type val[Size];

public:
    mystack() {cnt=0;}

    void emplace(int x) {
        val[++cnt] = x;
    }

    void pop() {
        --cnt;
    }

    Type top() {
        return val[cnt];
    }

    bool empty() {
        return cnt == 0;
    }

    void clear() {
        cnt = 0;
    }
}

docs.title: 分析句子提示词
docs.text:
提示词标签:

analysis_prompt

默认提示词:

Analyze the grammatical usage of '{word}' in this sentence: '{sentence}'
Focus on:
1. Tense (e.g., Present Simple, Past Perfect)
2. Voice (Active/Passive)
3. Mood (Indicative/Subjunctive)
4. Function (e.g., Subject, Object, Modifier)

Keep the analysis concise and technical. Output in 1 line. Example format:
"Present Simple, Active Voice. Functions as the subject of the sentence."

占位符:

  • {word}
  • {sentence}

docs.title: LexiGen
docs.text:
基于人工智能的首字母填空生成器。

在 GitHub 开源/下载

docs.title: 🎯 概述
docs.text: LexiGen 是一款 开源 的首字母填空生成器，零成本 使用本地 Ollama AI。

docs.title: 前置
docs.text:
1. 安装 Ollama
  2. 启动 Ollama 应用程序
  3. 打开终端（Windows：按 Windows + R，然后输入 cmd），并安装一个模型（推荐 qwen2.5:3b（质量更高，占用1.3GB） 或 qwen2.5:0.5b（模型更小，占用500MB）)：
ollama pull qwen2.5:3b

docs.title: 安装
docs.text:
1. 从 GitHub 或 蓝奏云盘 (密码：8hpe) 下载
  2. 选择您平台的对应版本
  3. 启动 LexiGen

注意，云盘的更新可能比较慢，所以优先从 GitHub Releases 中下载。

docs.title: 💡 自定义
docs.text: • 自定义 LexiGenAssets/prompt.txt 中的prompt，{word} 是您输入单词的占位符

docs.title: 📂 文件结构
docs.text:
LexiGenAssets 文件夹用于存放所有外部文件：

  • LexiGenAssets/ - 主资源目录
  • translations/ - 翻译文件（例如 zh_CN.json）
  • prompt.txt - 自定义提示模板文件
  • settings.yaml - 软件设置

docs.title: ⚠️ 故障排除
docs.text: 问题 解决方案 无法生成句子 检查 Ollama 服务器是否正在运行 连接错误 使用"检查服务器"按钮 生成缓慢 检查系统资源或使用更小的模型 qwen2.5:0.5b 模型错误 确认模型已安装

docs.title: 🤩 趣事
docs.text:
"Lexi" 来源于 "lexicon"（词典）。

我曾考虑过 "FibGen" 的名字 (Fill In the Blank)，但因为 "fib" 意为谎言，名字被替换为 "LexiGen"。

docs.title: LexiGen
docs.text:
An AI-powered desktop application for generating educational fill-in-the-blank sentences.

Available on GitHub

docs.title: 🎯 Overview
docs.text: LexiGen is an open-source fill-in-the-blank problems generator using local AI with Zero Cost.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
1. Install Ollama
  2. Launch the Ollama app
  3. Open the terminal (Windows: press Windows + R, then type cmd) and install a model (suggesting qwen2.5:3b or qwen2.5:0.5b (smaller)):
ollama pull qwen2.5:3b

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
1. Download LexiGen from the releases page
  2. Run the installer for your platform
  3. Launch LexiGen

docs.title: 💡 Best Practices
docs.text: • Customize the prompt in LexiGenAssets/prompt.txt, {word} is the placeholder for the target word

docs.title: 📂 File Structure
docs.text:
LexiGen now uses a dedicated LexiGenAssets folder for all external files:

  • LexiGenAssets/ - The main assets directory
  • translations/ - Translation files (e.g., zh_CN.json)
  • prompt.txt - Custom prompt template file
  • settings.yaml - Application settings

This structure separates application code from user data, making it easier to manage and backup your settings.

docs.title: ⚠️ Troubleshooting
docs.text: Issue Solution No sentence generation Check if Ollama server is running Connection errors Use 'Check Server' button Slow performance Verify system resources or use a smaller model qwen2.5:0.5b Model errors Confirm model installation

docs.title: 🤩 Fun Facts
docs.text:
"Lexi" comes from "lexicon".

I considered the name "FibGen" (Fill In the Blank). However, because "fib" means lie, this name was discarded.

docs.title: Untie
docs.text:
ios::sync_with_stdio(0);
cin.tie(0);
cout.tie(0);

Tip

The untied cin & cout are actually faster than scanf & printf.

Warning

You CANNOT use functions in <stdio> after untie, including printf(), scanf(), puts(), freopen().

docs.title: endl
docs.text:
endl can be about 10 times slower than the "\n".

#define endl '\n'

docs.title: Elapsed Time Measurement
C: FILE freopen()
docs.text:
head file: `

Definition
std::FILE* freopen( const char* filename, const char* mode, std::FILE* stream );

docs.title: File Access Mode String
docs.text:
From CPPReference

File access mode string Meaning Explanation Action if file already exists Action if file does not exist "r" read Open a file for reading read from start return NULL and set error "w" write Create a file for writing destroy contents create new "a" append Append to a file write to end create new "r+" read extended Open a file for read/write read from start return NULL and set error "w+" write extended Create a file for read/write destroy contents create new "a+" append extended Open a file for read/write write to end create new

Note

std::freopen is the only way to change the narrow/wide orientation of a stream once it has been established by an I/O operation or by std::fwide.

Example 
#include <cstdio>
#include <iostream>
using namespace std;

int main() {
    freopen("in.in", "r", stdin);
    freopen("out.out", "w", stdout);

    int a, b;
    cin >> a >> b;
    cout << a * a + b * b << endl;
    return 0;
}

Warning

If you have used the untie operation, you shouldn't use freopen because you would have already disabled <cstdio>.

Tip

If you are using an Online Judge, you can add this macro definition to your code:

ONLINE_JUDGE
#ifdef ONLINE_JUDGE
#else
#endif

Most OJ will use this macro definition, while your computer won't have one, thus you can add freopen in ONLINE_JUDGE so that you can use freopen as it'll be disabled on your OJ.

Example 
int main() {
    #ifdef ONLINE_JUDGE
    #else   // when run on local
        freopen("in.in", "r", "stdin");
        freopen("out.out", "w", "stdout");
    #endif
}

docs.title: headfile: <fiostream>
function open()
docs.text:
General UsingProtocol 
void open(const char * filename,
    ios_base::openmode mode = ios_base::in | ios::base::out);

void open(const wchar_t *_Filename,
    ios_base::in | ios_base::out, int prot = ios_base::_Openprot);
Parameters modeprot 
    ios::app: //open the file as append  

    ios::ate: //Locate the file to the end of the file when it is opened. ios:app includes this property.  

    ios::binary: //Open the file as binary, the default is text. See the previous section for the difference between the two methods  

    ios::in: // the file is opened as input (file data is entered into memory)  

    ios::out: //files are opened as output (memory data is output to the file)  

    ios::nocreate: //doesn't create the file, so it fails to open if the file doesn't exist  

    ios::noreplace: // doesn't overwrite the file, so opening the file fails if the file exists  

    ios::trunc: // set file length to 0 if file exists

    0: Ordinary file, open access  
    1: Read-only file  
    2: Implicit files  
    4: system file

Tip

You can use "or" or "+" to connect the above attributes, such as 3 or 1 | 2 is to open the file with read-only and implicit attributes.

docs.title: Difference Between GCC Optimizations
docs.text:
• O1: Enable basic optimizations, including function inlining and loop unrolling.
  • O2: Enable more optimizations, including function inlining, loop unrolling, constant propagation, dead code removal, etc.
  • O3: Enable more advanced optimizations, including function inlining, loop unrolling, constant propagation, dead code removal, vectorization, etc.
  • Os: Enable optimizations with code size reduction as the main goal.

Warning

Enabling higher-level optimization options may result in increased compilation times and, in some cases, may result in less efficient code execution.

Warning

Enabling GCC optimization manually is not allowed in Luogu OJ

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
Tip

If you have STL in your code, you'd better turn on O2 or even O3 optimization.

O2 Optimization
#pragma GCC optimize(2)
